trans-unit.source: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: The protocols supported by the Azure AD v2.0 app model public preview.
trans-unit.target: The protocols supported by the Azure AD v2.0 app model public preview.

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 app model provides identity-as-a-service for your apps by supporting industry standard protocols, OpenID Connect and OAuth 2.0. While the service is standard compliant, there can be subtle differences between any two implementations of these protocols. The information here will be useful if you choose to write your code by directly sending & handling HTTP requests, rather than using one of our open source libraries.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 app model provides identity-as-a-service for your apps by supporting industry standard protocols, OpenID Connect and OAuth 2.0. While the service is standard compliant, there can be subtle differences between any two implementations of these protocols. The information here will be useful if you choose to write your code by directly sending & handling HTTP requests, rather than using one of our open source libraries.

trans-unit.source: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.
trans-unit.target: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the <linkText>Azure Active Directory Developer Guide</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the <linkText>Azure Active Directory Developer Guide</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 app model's implementation of OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect make extensive use of bearer tokens, including bearer tokens represented as JWTs.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 app model's implementation of OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect make extensive use of bearer tokens, including bearer tokens represented as JWTs.

trans-unit.source: A bearer token is a lightweight security token that grants the “bearer” access to a protected resource.
trans-unit.target: A bearer token is a lightweight security token that grants the “bearer” access to a protected resource.

trans-unit.source: In this sense, the “bearer” is any party that can present the token.
trans-unit.target: In this sense, the “bearer” is any party that can present the token.

trans-unit.source: Though a party must first authenticate with Azure AD to receive the bearer token, if the required steps are not taken to secure the token in transmission and storage, it can be intercepted and used by an unintended party.
trans-unit.target: Though a party must first authenticate with Azure AD to receive the bearer token, if the required steps are not taken to secure the token in transmission and storage, it can be intercepted and used by an unintended party.

trans-unit.source: While some security tokens have a built-in mechanism for preventing unauthorized parties from using them, bearer tokens do not have this mechanism and must be transported in a secure channel such as transport layer security (HTTPS).
trans-unit.target: While some security tokens have a built-in mechanism for preventing unauthorized parties from using them, bearer tokens do not have this mechanism and must be transported in a secure channel such as transport layer security (HTTPS).

trans-unit.source: If a bearer token is transmitted in the clear, a man-in the middle attack can be used by a malicious party to acquire the token and use it for an unauthorized access to a protected resource.
trans-unit.target: If a bearer token is transmitted in the clear, a man-in the middle attack can be used by a malicious party to acquire the token and use it for an unauthorized access to a protected resource.

trans-unit.source: The same security principles apply when storing or caching bearer tokens for later use.
trans-unit.target: The same security principles apply when storing or caching bearer tokens for later use.

trans-unit.source: Always ensure that your app transmits and stores bearer tokens in a secure manner.
trans-unit.target: Always ensure that your app transmits and stores bearer tokens in a secure manner.

trans-unit.source: For more security considerations on bearer tokens, see <linkText>RFC 6750 Section 5</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more security considerations on bearer tokens, see <linkText>RFC 6750 Section 5</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Further details of different types of tokens used in the v2.0 app model is available in <linkText>the v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Further details of different types of tokens used in the v2.0 app model is available in <linkText>the v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Every app that uses the v2.0 app model will need to be registered at <linkText>apps.dev.microsoft.com</linkText><title></title>. The app registration process will collect & assign a few values to your app:
trans-unit.target: Every app that uses the v2.0 app model will need to be registered at <linkText>apps.dev.microsoft.com</linkText><title></title>. The app registration process will collect & assign a few values to your app:

trans-unit.source: An Application Id that uniquely identifies your app
trans-unit.target: An Application Id that uniquely identifies your app

trans-unit.source: A Redirect URI or Package Identifier that can be used to direct responses back to your app
trans-unit.target: A Redirect URI or Package Identifier that can be used to direct responses back to your app

trans-unit.source: A few other scenario-specific values.
trans-unit.target: A few other scenario-specific values.

trans-unit.source: For more detail, learn how to <linkText>register an app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more detail, learn how to <linkText>register an app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Once registered, the app communicates with Azure AD my sending requests to the v2.0 endpoint:
trans-unit.target: Once registered, the app communicates with Azure AD my sending requests to the v2.0 endpoint:

trans-unit.source: In nearly all OAuth & OpenID Connect flows, there are four parties involved in the exchange:
trans-unit.target: In nearly all OAuth & OpenID Connect flows, there are four parties involved in the exchange:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Roles</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Roles</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Authorization Server is the v2.0 Endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The Authorization Server is the v2.0 Endpoint.

trans-unit.source: It is responsible for ensuring the user's identity, granting and revoking access to resources, and issuing tokens.
trans-unit.target: It is responsible for ensuring the user's identity, granting and revoking access to resources, and issuing tokens.

trans-unit.source: It is also known as the identity provider - it securely handles anything to do with the user's information, their access, and the trust relationships between parties in an flow.
trans-unit.target: It is also known as the identity provider - it securely handles anything to do with the user's information, their access, and the trust relationships between parties in an flow.

trans-unit.source: The Resource Owner is typically the end-user.
trans-unit.target: The Resource Owner is typically the end-user.

trans-unit.source: It is the party that owns the data, and has the power to allow third parties to access that data, or resource.
trans-unit.target: It is the party that owns the data, and has the power to allow third parties to access that data, or resource.

trans-unit.source: The OAuth Client is your app, identified by its Application Id.
trans-unit.target: The OAuth Client is your app, identified by its Application Id.

trans-unit.source: It is usually the party that the end-user interacts with, and it requests tokens from the authorization server.
trans-unit.target: It is usually the party that the end-user interacts with, and it requests tokens from the authorization server.

trans-unit.source: The client must be granted permission to access the resource by the resource owner.
trans-unit.target: The client must be granted permission to access the resource by the resource owner.

trans-unit.source: The Resource Server is where the resource or data resides.
trans-unit.target: The Resource Server is where the resource or data resides.

trans-unit.source: It trusts the Authorization Server to securely authenticate and authorize the OAuth Client, and uses Bearer access_tokens to ensure that access to a resource can be granted.
trans-unit.target: It trusts the Authorization Server to securely authenticate and authorize the OAuth Client, and uses Bearer access_tokens to ensure that access to a resource can be granted.

trans-unit.source: The OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow is described in in <linkText>section 4.1 of the OAuth 2.0 specification</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow is described in in <linkText>section 4.1 of the OAuth 2.0 specification</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: It is used to perform authentication and authorization in the majority of app types, including <linkText>web apps</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>natively installed apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: It is used to perform authentication and authorization in the majority of app types, including <linkText>web apps</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>natively installed apps</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: It enables apps to securely acquire access_tokens which can be used to access resources that are secured using the v2.0 app model.
trans-unit.target: It enables apps to securely acquire access_tokens which can be used to access resources that are secured using the v2.0 app model.

trans-unit.source: Here is the entire flow for a native app; each request is detailed in the sections below: <linkText>OAuth Auth Code Flow</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Here is the entire flow for a native app; each request is detailed in the sections below: <linkText>OAuth Auth Code Flow</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The authorization code flow begins with the client directing the user to the /authorize endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The authorization code flow begins with the client directing the user to the /authorize endpoint.

trans-unit.source: In this request, the client indicates the permissions it needs to acquire from the user:
trans-unit.target: In this request, the client indicates the permissions it needs to acquire from the user:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: client_id
trans-unit.target: client_id

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The Application Id that the registration portal (<linkText>apps.dev.microsoft.com</linkText><title></title>) assigned your app.
trans-unit.target: The Application Id that the registration portal (<linkText>apps.dev.microsoft.com</linkText><title></title>) assigned your app.

trans-unit.source: response_type
trans-unit.target: response_type

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: Must include code for the authorization code flow.
trans-unit.target: Must include code for the authorization code flow.

trans-unit.source: redirect_uri
trans-unit.target: redirect_uri

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The redirect_uri of your app, where authentication responses can be sent and receieved by your app.
trans-unit.target: The redirect_uri of your app, where authentication responses can be sent and receieved by your app.

trans-unit.source: It must exactly match one of the redirect_uris you registered in the portal, except it must be url encoded.
trans-unit.target: It must exactly match one of the redirect_uris you registered in the portal, except it must be url encoded.

trans-unit.source: scope
trans-unit.target: scope

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: A space-separated list of scopes. A single scope value indicates to the v2.0 endpoint both the resource and the permissions to that resource being requested. Scopes take the form /. In the example above, the app identifier for the Azure AD Graph API is used, https://graph.windows.net, and two permissions are requested: directory.read and directory.write. For a more detailed explanation of scopes, refer to c.
trans-unit.target: A space-separated list of scopes. A single scope value indicates to the v2.0 endpoint both the resource and the permissions to that resource being requested. Scopes take the form /. In the example above, the app identifier for the Azure AD Graph API is used, https://graph.windows.net, and two permissions are requested: directory.read and directory.write. For a more detailed explanation of scopes, refer to c.

trans-unit.source: response_mode
trans-unit.target: response_mode

trans-unit.source: recommended
trans-unit.target: recommended

trans-unit.source: Specifies the method that should be used to send the resulting authorization_code back to your app.
trans-unit.target: Specifies the method that should be used to send the resulting authorization_code back to your app.

trans-unit.source: Can be one of 'query', 'form_post', or 'fragment'.
trans-unit.target: Can be one of 'query', 'form_post', or 'fragment'.

trans-unit.source: state
trans-unit.target: state

trans-unit.source: recommended
trans-unit.target: recommended

trans-unit.source: A value included in the request that will also be returned in the token response.
trans-unit.target: A value included in the request that will also be returned in the token response.

trans-unit.source: It can be a string of any content that you wish.
trans-unit.target: It can be a string of any content that you wish.

trans-unit.source: A randomly generated unique value is typically used for preventing cross-site request forgery attacks.
trans-unit.target: A randomly generated unique value is typically used for preventing cross-site request forgery attacks.

trans-unit.source: The state is also used to encode information about the user's state in the app before the authentication request occurred, such as the page or view they were on.
trans-unit.target: The state is also used to encode information about the user's state in the app before the authentication request occurred, such as the page or view they were on.

trans-unit.source: prompt
trans-unit.target: prompt

trans-unit.source: optional
trans-unit.target: optional

trans-unit.source: Indicates the type of user interaction that is required.
trans-unit.target: Indicates the type of user interaction that is required.

trans-unit.source: The only valid value at this time is 'login', which forces the user to enter their credentials on that request.
trans-unit.target: The only valid value at this time is 'login', which forces the user to enter their credentials on that request.

trans-unit.source: Single-sign on will not take effect.
trans-unit.target: Single-sign on will not take effect.

trans-unit.source: At this point, the user will be asked to enter their credentials and complete the authentication.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the user will be asked to enter their credentials and complete the authentication.

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 endpoint will also ensure that the user has consented to the permissions indicated in the scope query parameter.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 endpoint will also ensure that the user has consented to the permissions indicated in the scope query parameter.

trans-unit.source: If the user has not consented to any of those permissions, it will ask the user to consent to the required permissions.
trans-unit.target: If the user has not consented to any of those permissions, it will ask the user to consent to the required permissions.

trans-unit.source: Details of <linkText>permissions, consent, and multi-tenant apps are provided here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Details of <linkText>permissions, consent, and multi-tenant apps are provided here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Once the user authenticates and grants consent, the v2.0 endpoint will return a response to your app at the indicated redirect_uri, using the method specified in the response_mode parameter.
trans-unit.target: Once the user authenticates and grants consent, the v2.0 endpoint will return a response to your app at the indicated redirect_uri, using the method specified in the response_mode parameter.

trans-unit.source: A successful response using response_mode=query looks like:
trans-unit.target: A successful response using response_mode=query looks like:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: code
trans-unit.target: code

trans-unit.source: The authorization_code that the app requested.
trans-unit.target: The authorization_code that the app requested.

trans-unit.source: The app can use the authorization code to request an access token for the target resource.
trans-unit.target: The app can use the authorization code to request an access token for the target resource.

trans-unit.source: Authorization_codes are very short lived, typically they expire after about 10 minutes.
trans-unit.target: Authorization_codes are very short lived, typically they expire after about 10 minutes.

trans-unit.source: session_state
trans-unit.target: session_state

trans-unit.source: A unique value that identifies the current user session.
trans-unit.target: A unique value that identifies the current user session.

trans-unit.source: This value is a GUID, but should be treated as an opaque value that is passed without examination.
trans-unit.target: This value is a GUID, but should be treated as an opaque value that is passed without examination.

trans-unit.source: state
trans-unit.target: state

trans-unit.source: If a state parameter is included in the request, the same value should appear in the response.
trans-unit.target: If a state parameter is included in the request, the same value should appear in the response.

trans-unit.source: The app should verify that the state values in the request and response are identical.
trans-unit.target: The app should verify that the state values in the request and response are identical.

trans-unit.source: Error responses may also be sent to the redirect_uri so the app can handle them appropriately:
trans-unit.target: Error responses may also be sent to the redirect_uri so the app can handle them appropriately:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: error
trans-unit.target: error

trans-unit.source: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.
trans-unit.target: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.

trans-unit.source: error_description
trans-unit.target: error_description

trans-unit.source: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.
trans-unit.target: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've acquired an authorization_code and have been granted permission by the user, you can redeem the code for an access_token to the desired resource, by sending a POST request to the /token endpoint:
trans-unit.target: Now that you've acquired an authorization_code and have been granted permission by the user, you can redeem the code for an access_token to the desired resource, by sending a POST request to the /token endpoint:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: client_id
trans-unit.target: client_id

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The Application Id that the registration portal (<linkText>apps.dev.microsoft.com</linkText><title></title>) assigned your app.
trans-unit.target: The Application Id that the registration portal (<linkText>apps.dev.microsoft.com</linkText><title></title>) assigned your app.

trans-unit.source: grant_type
trans-unit.target: grant_type

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: Must be authorization_code for the authorization code flow.
trans-unit.target: Must be authorization_code for the authorization code flow.

trans-unit.source: scope
trans-unit.target: scope

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: A space-separated list of scopes.
trans-unit.target: A space-separated list of scopes.

trans-unit.source: The scopes requested in this leg must be equivalent to or a subset of the scopes requested in the first leg.
trans-unit.target: The scopes requested in this leg must be equivalent to or a subset of the scopes requested in the first leg.

trans-unit.source: If the scopes specified in this request span multiple resource servers, then the v2.0 endpoint will return a token for the resource specified in the first scope.
trans-unit.target: If the scopes specified in this request span multiple resource servers, then the v2.0 endpoint will return a token for the resource specified in the first scope.

trans-unit.source: For a more detailed explanation of scopes, refer to <linkText>permissions, consent, and scopes</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a more detailed explanation of scopes, refer to <linkText>permissions, consent, and scopes</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: code
trans-unit.target: code

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The authorization_code that you acquired in the first leg of the flow.
trans-unit.target: The authorization_code that you acquired in the first leg of the flow.

trans-unit.source: client_secret
trans-unit.target: client_secret

trans-unit.source: required for web apps
trans-unit.target: required for web apps

trans-unit.source: The application secret that you created in the app registration portal for your app.
trans-unit.target: The application secret that you created in the app registration portal for your app.

trans-unit.source: It should not be used in a native app, because client_secrets cannot be reliably stored on devices.
trans-unit.target: It should not be used in a native app, because client_secrets cannot be reliably stored on devices.

trans-unit.source: It is required for web apps and web APIs, which have the ability to store the client_secret securely on the server side.
trans-unit.target: It is required for web apps and web APIs, which have the ability to store the client_secret securely on the server side.

trans-unit.source: A successful token response will look like:
trans-unit.target: A successful token response will look like:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: access_token
trans-unit.target: access_token

trans-unit.source: The requested access token.
trans-unit.target: The requested access token.

trans-unit.source: The app can use this token to authenticate to the secured resource, such as a web API.
trans-unit.target: The app can use this token to authenticate to the secured resource, such as a web API.

trans-unit.source: token_type
trans-unit.target: token_type

trans-unit.source: Indicates the token type value.
trans-unit.target: Indicates the token type value.

trans-unit.source: The only type that Azure AD supports is Bearer
trans-unit.target: The only type that Azure AD supports is Bearer

trans-unit.source: expires_in
trans-unit.target: expires_in

trans-unit.source: How long the access token is valid (in seconds).
trans-unit.target: How long the access token is valid (in seconds).

trans-unit.source: expires_on
trans-unit.target: expires_on

trans-unit.source: The time when the access token expires.
trans-unit.target: The time when the access token expires.

trans-unit.source: The date is represented as the number of seconds from the epoch time.
trans-unit.target: The date is represented as the number of seconds from the epoch time.

trans-unit.source: scope
trans-unit.target: scope

trans-unit.source: The scopes that the access_token is valid for.
trans-unit.target: The scopes that the access_token is valid for.

trans-unit.source: refresh_token
trans-unit.target: refresh_token

trans-unit.source: An OAuth 2.0 refresh token.
trans-unit.target: An OAuth 2.0 refresh token.

trans-unit.source: The app can use this token acquire additional access tokens after the current access token expires.
trans-unit.target: The app can use this token acquire additional access tokens after the current access token expires.

trans-unit.source: Refresh_tokens are long-lived, and can be used to retain access to resources for extended periods of time.
trans-unit.target: Refresh_tokens are long-lived, and can be used to retain access to resources for extended periods of time.

trans-unit.source: For more detail, refer to the <linkText>v2.0 token reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more detail, refer to the <linkText>v2.0 token reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: id_token
trans-unit.target: id_token

trans-unit.source: An unsigned JSON Web Token (JWT).
trans-unit.target: An unsigned JSON Web Token (JWT).

trans-unit.source: The app can base64Url decode the segments of this token to request information about the user who signed in.
trans-unit.target: The app can base64Url decode the segments of this token to request information about the user who signed in.

trans-unit.source: The app can cache the values and display them, but it should not rely on them for any authorization or security boundaries.
trans-unit.target: The app can cache the values and display them, but it should not rely on them for any authorization or security boundaries.

trans-unit.source: For more information about id_tokens see the <linkText>v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about id_tokens see the <linkText>v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Error responses will look like:
trans-unit.target: Error responses will look like:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: error
trans-unit.target: error

trans-unit.source: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.
trans-unit.target: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.

trans-unit.source: error_description
trans-unit.target: error_description

trans-unit.source: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.
trans-unit.target: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've successfully acquired an access_token, you can use the token in reqeusts to Web APIs by including it in the Authorization header:
trans-unit.target: Now that you've successfully acquired an access_token, you can use the token in reqeusts to Web APIs by including it in the Authorization header:

trans-unit.source: Access_tokens are short lived, and you must refresh them after they expire to continue accessing resources.
trans-unit.target: Access_tokens are short lived, and you must refresh them after they expire to continue accessing resources.

trans-unit.source: You can do so by submitting another POST request to the /authorize endpoint, this time providing the refresh_token instead of the code:
trans-unit.target: You can do so by submitting another POST request to the /authorize endpoint, this time providing the refresh_token instead of the code:

trans-unit.target: client_id

trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.target: The Application Id that the registration portal (<linkText>apps.dev.microsoft.com</linkText><title></title>) assigned your app.

trans-unit.source: It should not be used in a native app, because client_secrets cannot be reliably stored on devices.

trans-unit.source: It is required for web apps and web APIs, which have the ability to store the client_secret securely on the server side.

trans-unit.target: access_token

trans-unit.source: The requested access token.
trans-unit.target: The requested access token.

trans-unit.source: The app can use this token to authenticate to the secured resource, such as a web API.
trans-unit.target: The app can use this token to authenticate to the secured resource, such as a web API.

trans-unit.source: token_type
trans-unit.target: token_type

trans-unit.source: Indicates the token type value.
trans-unit.target: Indicates the token type value.

trans-unit.source: The only type that Azure AD supports is Bearer
trans-unit.target: The only type that Azure AD supports is Bearer

trans-unit.source: expires_in
trans-unit.target: expires_in

trans-unit.source: How long the access token is valid (in seconds).
trans-unit.target: How long the access token is valid (in seconds).

trans-unit.source: expires_on
trans-unit.target: expires_on

trans-unit.source: The time when the access token expires.
trans-unit.target: The time when the access token expires.

trans-unit.source: The date is represented as the number of seconds from the epoch time.
trans-unit.target: The date is represented as the number of seconds from the epoch time.

trans-unit.source: scope
trans-unit.target: scope

trans-unit.source: The scopes that the access_token is valid for.
trans-unit.target: The scopes that the access_token is valid for.

trans-unit.source: refresh_token
trans-unit.target: refresh_token

trans-unit.source: A new OAuth 2.0 refresh token.
trans-unit.target: A new OAuth 2.0 refresh token.

trans-unit.source: You should replace the old refresh token with this newly acquired refresh token to ensure your refresh tokens remain valid for as long as possible.
trans-unit.target: You should replace the old refresh token with this newly acquired refresh token to ensure your refresh tokens remain valid for as long as possible.

trans-unit.source: id_token
trans-unit.target: id_token

trans-unit.source: An unsigned JSON Web Token (JWT).
trans-unit.target: An unsigned JSON Web Token (JWT).

trans-unit.source: The app can base64Url decode the segements of this token to request information about the user who signed in.
trans-unit.target: The app can base64Url decode the segements of this token to request information about the user who signed in.

trans-unit.source: The app can cache the values and display them, but it should not rely on them for any authorization or security boundaries.
trans-unit.target: The app can cache the values and display them, but it should not rely on them for any authorization or security boundaries.

trans-unit.source: For more information about id_tokens see the <linkText>v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about id_tokens see the <linkText>v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Error responses will look like:
trans-unit.target: Error responses will look like:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: error
trans-unit.target: error

trans-unit.source: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.
trans-unit.target: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.

trans-unit.source: error_description
trans-unit.target: error_description

trans-unit.source: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.
trans-unit.target: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.

trans-unit.source: OpenID Connect extends the OAuth 2.0 authorization protocol for use as an authentication protocol, which allows you to perform single sign-on using OAuth.
trans-unit.target: OpenID Connect extends the OAuth 2.0 authorization protocol for use as an authentication protocol, which allows you to perform single sign-on using OAuth.

trans-unit.source: It introduces the concept of an id_token, which is a security token that allows the client to verify the identity of the user and obtain basic profile information about the user.
trans-unit.target: It introduces the concept of an id_token, which is a security token that allows the client to verify the identity of the user and obtain basic profile information about the user.

trans-unit.source: OpenID Connect for the v2.0 app model is the recommended way to implement sign-in for a <linkText>web app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: OpenID Connect for the v2.0 app model is the recommended way to implement sign-in for a <linkText>web app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The most basic sign-in flow contains the following steps:
trans-unit.target: The most basic sign-in flow contains the following steps:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>OpenId Connect Swimlanes</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>OpenId Connect Swimlanes</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When your web app needs to authenticate the user, it can direct the user to the /authorize endpoint.
trans-unit.target: When your web app needs to authenticate the user, it can direct the user to the /authorize endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This request is similar to the first leg of the <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code Flow</linkText><title></title>, with a few important distinctions:
trans-unit.target: This request is similar to the first leg of the <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code Flow</linkText><title></title>, with a few important distinctions:

trans-unit.source: The request must include the scope openid in the scope parameter.
trans-unit.target: The request must include the scope openid in the scope parameter.

trans-unit.source: The response_type parameter must include id_token
trans-unit.target: The response_type parameter must include id_token

trans-unit.source: The request must include the nonce parameter
trans-unit.target: The request must include the nonce parameter

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: client_id
trans-unit.target: client_id

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The Application Id that the registration portal (<linkText>apps.dev.microsoft.com</linkText><title></title>) assigned your app.
trans-unit.target: The Application Id that the registration portal (<linkText>apps.dev.microsoft.com</linkText><title></title>) assigned your app.

trans-unit.source: response_type
trans-unit.target: response_type

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: Must include id_token for OpenID Connect sign-in.
trans-unit.target: Must include id_token for OpenID Connect sign-in.

trans-unit.source: It may also include other response_types, as described in the <linkText>OpenID Connect with OAuth Code Flow </linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: It may also include other response_types, as described in the <linkText>OpenID Connect with OAuth Code Flow </linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: redirect_uri
trans-unit.target: redirect_uri

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The redirect_uri of your app, where authentication responses can be sent and received by your app.
trans-unit.target: The redirect_uri of your app, where authentication responses can be sent and received by your app.

trans-unit.source: It must exactly match one of the redirect_uris you registered in the portal, except it must be url encoded.
trans-unit.target: It must exactly match one of the redirect_uris you registered in the portal, except it must be url encoded.

trans-unit.source: scope
trans-unit.target: scope

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: A space-separated list of scopes. For OpenID Connect, it must include the scope openid, which translates to the "Sign in & Read Your Profile" permission in the consent UI. You may also include other scopes in this request for requesting consent, as described in the OpenID Connect with OAuth Code Flow section.
trans-unit.target: A space-separated list of scopes. For OpenID Connect, it must include the scope openid, which translates to the "Sign in & Read Your Profile" permission in the consent UI. You may also include other scopes in this request for requesting consent, as described in the OpenID Connect with OAuth Code Flow section.

trans-unit.source: nonce
trans-unit.target: nonce

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: A value included in the request, generated by the app, that will included in the resulting id_token as a claim.
trans-unit.target: A value included in the request, generated by the app, that will included in the resulting id_token as a claim.

trans-unit.source: The app can then verify this value to mitigate token replay attacks.
trans-unit.target: The app can then verify this value to mitigate token replay attacks.

trans-unit.source: The value is typically a randomized, unique string that can be used to identify the origin of the request.
trans-unit.target: The value is typically a randomized, unique string that can be used to identify the origin of the request.

trans-unit.source: response_mode
trans-unit.target: response_mode

trans-unit.source: recommended
trans-unit.target: recommended

trans-unit.source: Specifies the method that should be used to send the resulting authorization_code back to your app.
trans-unit.target: Specifies the method that should be used to send the resulting authorization_code back to your app.

trans-unit.source: Can be one of 'query', 'form_post', or 'fragment'.
trans-unit.target: Can be one of 'query', 'form_post', or 'fragment'.

trans-unit.source: state
trans-unit.target: state

trans-unit.source: recommended
trans-unit.target: recommended

trans-unit.source: A value included in the request that will also be returned in the token response.
trans-unit.target: A value included in the request that will also be returned in the token response.

trans-unit.source: It can be a string of any content that you wish.
trans-unit.target: It can be a string of any content that you wish.

trans-unit.source: A randomly generated unique value is typically used for preventing cross-site request forgery attacks.
trans-unit.target: A randomly generated unique value is typically used for preventing cross-site request forgery attacks.

trans-unit.source: The state is also used to encode information about the user's state in the app before the authentication request occurred, such as the page or view they were on.
trans-unit.target: The state is also used to encode information about the user's state in the app before the authentication request occurred, such as the page or view they were on.

trans-unit.source: prompt
trans-unit.target: prompt

trans-unit.source: optional
trans-unit.target: optional

trans-unit.source: Indicates the type of user interaction that is required.
trans-unit.target: Indicates the type of user interaction that is required.

trans-unit.source: The only valid value at this time is 'login', which forces the user to enter their credentials on that request.
trans-unit.target: The only valid value at this time is 'login', which forces the user to enter their credentials on that request.

trans-unit.source: Single-sign on will not take effect.
trans-unit.target: Single-sign on will not take effect.

trans-unit.source: At this point, the user will be asked to enter their credentials and complete the authentication.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the user will be asked to enter their credentials and complete the authentication.

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 endpoint will also ensure that the user has consented to the permissions indicated in the scope query parameter.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 endpoint will also ensure that the user has consented to the permissions indicated in the scope query parameter.

trans-unit.source: If the user has not consented to any of those permissions, it will ask the user to consent to the required permissions.
trans-unit.target: If the user has not consented to any of those permissions, it will ask the user to consent to the required permissions.

trans-unit.source: Details of <linkText>permissions, consent, and multi-tenant apps are provided here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Details of <linkText>permissions, consent, and multi-tenant apps are provided here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Once the user authenticates and grants consent, the v2.0 endpoint will return a response to your app at the indicated redirect_uri, using the method specified in the response_mode parameter.
trans-unit.target: Once the user authenticates and grants consent, the v2.0 endpoint will return a response to your app at the indicated redirect_uri, using the method specified in the response_mode parameter.

trans-unit.source: A successful response using response_mode=query looks like:
trans-unit.target: A successful response using response_mode=query looks like:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: id_token
trans-unit.target: id_token

trans-unit.source: The id_token that the app requested.
trans-unit.target: The id_token that the app requested.

trans-unit.source: You can use the id_token to verify the user's identity and begin a session with the user.
trans-unit.target: You can use the id_token to verify the user's identity and begin a session with the user.

trans-unit.source: More details on id_tokens and their contents is included in the <linkText>v2.0 endpoint token reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: More details on id_tokens and their contents is included in the <linkText>v2.0 endpoint token reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: session_state
trans-unit.target: session_state

trans-unit.source: A unique value that identifies the current user session.
trans-unit.target: A unique value that identifies the current user session.

trans-unit.source: This value is a GUID, but should be treated as an opaque value that is passed without examination.
trans-unit.target: This value is a GUID, but should be treated as an opaque value that is passed without examination.

trans-unit.source: state
trans-unit.target: state

trans-unit.source: If a state parameter is included in the request, the same value should appear in the response.
trans-unit.target: If a state parameter is included in the request, the same value should appear in the response.

trans-unit.source: The app should verify that the state values in the request and response are identical.
trans-unit.target: The app should verify that the state values in the request and response are identical.

trans-unit.source: Error responses may also be sent to the redirect_uri so the app can handle them appropriately:
trans-unit.target: Error responses may also be sent to the redirect_uri so the app can handle them appropriately:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: error
trans-unit.target: error

trans-unit.source: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.
trans-unit.target: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.

trans-unit.source: error_description
trans-unit.target: error_description

trans-unit.source: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.
trans-unit.target: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.

trans-unit.source: Just receiving an idtoken is not sufficient to authenticate the user; you must validate the idtoken's signature and verify the claims in the token per your app's requirements.
trans-unit.target: Just receiving an idtoken is not sufficient to authenticate the user; you must validate the idtoken's signature and verify the claims in the token per your app's requirements.

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 endpoint uses <linkText>JSON Web Tokens (JWTs)</linkText><title></title> and public key cryptography to sign tokens and verify that they are valid.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 endpoint uses <linkText>JSON Web Tokens (JWTs)</linkText><title></title> and public key cryptography to sign tokens and verify that they are valid.

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 app model has an OpenID Connect metadata endpoint, which allows an app to fetch information about the v2.0 app model at runtime.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 app model has an OpenID Connect metadata endpoint, which allows an app to fetch information about the v2.0 app model at runtime.

trans-unit.source: This information includes endpoints, token contents, and token signing keys.
trans-unit.target: This information includes endpoints, token contents, and token signing keys.

trans-unit.source: The metadata endpoint contains a JSON document located at:
trans-unit.target: The metadata endpoint contains a JSON document located at:

trans-unit.source: https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/v2.0/.well-known/configuration
trans-unit.target: https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/v2.0/.well-known/configuration

trans-unit.source: One of the properties of this configuration document is the jwks_uri, whose value for the v2.0 app model will be:
trans-unit.target: One of the properties of this configuration document is the jwks_uri, whose value for the v2.0 app model will be:

trans-unit.source: https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/discovery/v2.0/keys.
trans-unit.target: https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/discovery/v2.0/keys.

trans-unit.source: You can use the RSA256 public keys located at this endpoint to validate the signature of the id_token.
trans-unit.target: You can use the RSA256 public keys located at this endpoint to validate the signature of the id_token.

trans-unit.source: There are multiple keys listed at this endpoint at any given point in time, each identified by a kid.
trans-unit.target: There are multiple keys listed at this endpoint at any given point in time, each identified by a kid.

trans-unit.source: The header of the id_token also contains a kid claim, which indicates which of these keys was used to sign the id_token.
trans-unit.target: The header of the id_token also contains a kid claim, which indicates which of these keys was used to sign the id_token.

trans-unit.source: See the <linkText>v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title> for more information, including <linkText>Validating Tokens</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Important Information About Signing Key Rollover</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: See the <linkText>v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title> for more information, including <linkText>Validating Tokens</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Important Information About Signing Key Rollover</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Once you've validated the signature of the id_token, there are a few claims you will need to verify:
trans-unit.target: Once you've validated the signature of the id_token, there are a few claims you will need to verify:

trans-unit.source: You should validate the nonce claim to prevent token replay attacks.
trans-unit.target: You should validate the nonce claim to prevent token replay attacks.

trans-unit.source: Its value should be what you specified in the sign-in request.
trans-unit.target: Its value should be what you specified in the sign-in request.

trans-unit.source: You should validate the aud claim to ensure the id_token was issued for your app.
trans-unit.target: You should validate the aud claim to ensure the id_token was issued for your app.

trans-unit.source: Its value should be the client_id of your app.
trans-unit.target: Its value should be the client_id of your app.

trans-unit.source: You should validate the iat and exp claims to ensure the id_token has not expired.
trans-unit.target: You should validate the iat and exp claims to ensure the id_token has not expired.

trans-unit.source: You may also wish to validate additional claims depending on your scenario.
trans-unit.target: You may also wish to validate additional claims depending on your scenario.

trans-unit.source: Some common validations include:
trans-unit.target: Some common validations include:

trans-unit.source: Ensuring the user/organization has signed up for the app.
trans-unit.target: Ensuring the user/organization has signed up for the app.

trans-unit.source: Ensuring the user has proper authorization/privileges
trans-unit.target: Ensuring the user has proper authorization/privileges

trans-unit.source: Ensuring a certain strength of authentication has occurred, such as multi-factor authentication.
trans-unit.target: Ensuring a certain strength of authentication has occurred, such as multi-factor authentication.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the claims in an id_token, see the <linkText>v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on the claims in an id_token, see the <linkText>v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Once you have completely validated the idtoken, you can begin a session with the user and use the claims in the idtoken to obtain information about the user in your app.
trans-unit.target: Once you have completely validated the idtoken, you can begin a session with the user and use the claims in the idtoken to obtain information about the user in your app.

trans-unit.source: This information can be used for display, records, authorizations, etc.
trans-unit.target: This information can be used for display, records, authorizations, etc.

trans-unit.source: The OpenIdConnect end_session_endpoint is not currently supported by the v2.0 app model preview.
trans-unit.target: The OpenIdConnect end_session_endpoint is not currently supported by the v2.0 app model preview.

trans-unit.source: This means your app cannot send a request to the v2.0 endpoint to end a user's session and clear cookies set by the v2.0 endpoint.
trans-unit.target: This means your app cannot send a request to the v2.0 endpoint to end a user's session and clear cookies set by the v2.0 endpoint.

trans-unit.source: To sign a user out, your app can simply end its own session with the user, and leave the user's session with the v2.0 endpoint in-tact.
trans-unit.target: To sign a user out, your app can simply end its own session with the user, and leave the user's session with the v2.0 endpoint in-tact.

trans-unit.source: The next time the user tries to sign in, they will see a "choose account" page, with their actively signed-in accounts listed.
trans-unit.target: The next time the user tries to sign in, they will see a "choose account" page, with their actively signed-in accounts listed.

trans-unit.source: On that page, the user can choose to sign out of any account, ending the session with the v2.0 endpoint.
trans-unit.target: On that page, the user can choose to sign out of any account, ending the session with the v2.0 endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Many web apps need to sign the user in and then access a web service on behalf of that user using OAuth.
trans-unit.target: Many web apps need to sign the user in and then access a web service on behalf of that user using OAuth.

trans-unit.source: This scenario combines the two above sections - it uses OpenID Connect for user authentication while simultaneously acquiring an authorizationcode that can be used to get accesstokens using the OAuth Authorization Code Flow:
trans-unit.target: This scenario combines the two above sections - it uses OpenID Connect for user authentication while simultaneously acquiring an authorizationcode that can be used to get accesstokens using the OAuth Authorization Code Flow:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>OpenId Connect Swimlanes</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>OpenId Connect Swimlanes</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This flow only slightly differs from the above sections, in how you send the sign-in request.
trans-unit.target: This flow only slightly differs from the above sections, in how you send the sign-in request.

trans-unit.source: When your web app needs to authenticate the user & get the permissions it needs to access resources, it can direct the user to the /authorize endpoint. In this case, your app must ask for both an id_token and a code in the response:
trans-unit.target: When your web app needs to authenticate the user & get the permissions it needs to access resources, it can direct the user to the /authorize endpoint. In this case, your app must ask for both an id_token and a code in the response:

trans-unit.target: Details of <linkText>permissions, consent, and multi-tenant apps are provided here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Once the user authenticates and grants consent, the v2.0 endpoint will return a response to your app at the indicated redirect_uri, using the method specified in the response_mode parameter.
trans-unit.target: Once the user authenticates and grants consent, the v2.0 endpoint will return a response to your app at the indicated redirect_uri, using the method specified in the response_mode parameter.

trans-unit.source: A successful response using response_mode=query looks like:
trans-unit.target: A successful response using response_mode=query looks like:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: id_token
trans-unit.target: id_token

trans-unit.source: The id_token that the app requested.
trans-unit.target: The id_token that the app requested.

trans-unit.source: You can use the id_token to verify the user's identity and begin a session with the user.
trans-unit.target: You can use the id_token to verify the user's identity and begin a session with the user.

trans-unit.source: More details on id_tokens and their contents is included in the <linkText>v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: More details on id_tokens and their contents is included in the <linkText>v2.0 app model token reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: code
trans-unit.target: code

trans-unit.source: The authorization_code that the app requested.
trans-unit.target: The authorization_code that the app requested.

trans-unit.source: The app can use the authorization code to request an access token for the target resource.
trans-unit.target: The app can use the authorization code to request an access token for the target resource.

trans-unit.source: Authorization_codes are very short lived, typically they expire after about 10 minutes.
trans-unit.target: Authorization_codes are very short lived, typically they expire after about 10 minutes.

trans-unit.source: session_state
trans-unit.target: session_state

trans-unit.source: A unique value that identifies the current user session.
trans-unit.target: A unique value that identifies the current user session.

trans-unit.source: This value is a GUID, but should be treated as an opaque value that is passed without examination.
trans-unit.target: This value is a GUID, but should be treated as an opaque value that is passed without examination.

trans-unit.source: state
trans-unit.target: state

trans-unit.source: If a state parameter is included in the request, the same value should appear in the response.
trans-unit.target: If a state parameter is included in the request, the same value should appear in the response.

trans-unit.source: The app should verify that the state values in the request and response are identical.
trans-unit.target: The app should verify that the state values in the request and response are identical.

trans-unit.source: Error responses may also be sent to the redirect_uri so the app can handle them appropriately:
trans-unit.target: Error responses may also be sent to the redirect_uri so the app can handle them appropriately:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: error
trans-unit.target: error

trans-unit.source: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.
trans-unit.target: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.

trans-unit.source: error_description
trans-unit.target: error_description

trans-unit.source: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.
trans-unit.target: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.

trans-unit.target: This process is exactly the same as described above in the <linkText>OpenID Connect Sign-In Flow</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.target: This process is exactly the same as described above in the <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code Flow</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials Grant is described in the <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Specification</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials Grant is described in the <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Specification</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: It is useful for long running processes and other server to server scenarios, where the app can authenticate to a resource using its own "Application Identity", rather than a user's delegated identity.
trans-unit.target: It is useful for long running processes and other server to server scenarios, where the app can authenticate to a resource using its own "Application Identity", rather than a user's delegated identity.

trans-unit.target: This flow is not currently supported by the v2.0 app model preview.

trans-unit.source: The OAuth 2.0 Implicit Flow is described in the <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Specification</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The OAuth 2.0 Implicit Flow is described in the <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Specification</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: It is often used for single-page/javascript apps that run in a browser.
trans-unit.target: It is often used for single-page/javascript apps that run in a browser.

trans-unit.source: This flow is not currently supported by the v2.0 app model preview.
trans-unit.target: This flow is not currently supported by the v2.0 app model preview.

trans-unit.source: To see how it works in the generally available Azure AD service, see <linkText>this Azure AD code sample</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To see how it works in the generally available Azure AD service, see <linkText>this Azure AD code sample</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The OAuth 2.0 Resource Owner Password Credentials Grant is described in the <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Specification</linkText><title></title>. It allows an app to acquire access_tokens by providing a user's username & password in a token request.
trans-unit.target: The OAuth 2.0 Resource Owner Password Credentials Grant is described in the <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Specification</linkText><title></title>. It allows an app to acquire access_tokens by providing a user's username & password in a token request.

trans-unit.source: This flow is not currently supported by the v2.0 app model preview.
trans-unit.target: This flow is not currently supported by the v2.0 app model preview.

trans-unit.source: To see how it works in the generally available Azure AD service, see <linkText>this Azure AD code sample</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To see how it works in the generally available Azure AD service, see <linkText>this Azure AD code sample</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The On Behalf Of Flow, or JWT Bearer Credentials Grant is described in this <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Extension Grant Draft</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The On Behalf Of Flow, or JWT Bearer Credentials Grant is described in this <linkText>OAuth 2.0 Extension Grant Draft</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: It allows a Web API that receives an accesstoken to use that accesstoken as a credential for acquiring access_tokens to other resources.
trans-unit.target: It allows a Web API that receives an accesstoken to use that accesstoken as a credential for acquiring access_tokens to other resources.

trans-unit.source: This allows a Web API to securely call another downstream Web API.
trans-unit.target: This allows a Web API to securely call another downstream Web API.

trans-unit.source: This flow is not currently supported by the v2.0 app model preview.
trans-unit.target: This flow is not currently supported by the v2.0 app model preview.
